title: Measuring Postgraduate Success
text:
Measuring Postgraduate Success, by Xavi Wernli, Munya Masvaure, and Laurice Jimu. Link to presentation slides: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1bwKRb_46IZ1M0plZareMSoo_621B3abiz2UghWiyz5g/edit?usp=sharing Link to presentation video: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1OgBqoxMqjv8b96oMTSazWFif5Lxv3k4-/view?usp=sharing
We did this project to try and better understand the relationship between economic and personal success. While the original research question asked how success relates to geography, it quickly became more about the difference between the two successes. We categorize economic success as the average middle career income of graduates at a specific university, while personal success is the percentage of graduates who feel their job makes the world a better place. All of the data was sourced from Kaggle, though two datasets had to be combined for this data. In addition, to understand the relationship between success and school category, the category variable was created.
General scatter plot






This first graph shows how as the mid-career pay of graduates increase, they tend to feel less personal success. However, as income get very high, the amount of personal success felt by graduates appears to increase. This is likely due to the decreased number of data points at that income.
Scatter plot including stem percentage






This next graph demonstrates that jobs in stem tend to make more money than non-stem jobs, however not necessarily an increased or decreased amount of personal success.
Faceted scatter plot by region






This graph shows that personal and financial success varies a lot by region. This is partly due to some areas generally having higher incomes, leading to more income variability. Due to there often being less data points, it is difficult to see the trend in personal success, as some regions have very few higher income graduates.
Scatter plot by school category






This graph shows the relationship between school category and success. One very clear trend is the group of medical schools at the top middle of the screen. These schools don’t necessarily have a super high income, but have very high levels of personal success.
Faceted scatter plot by school category






This is a faceted version of the previous graph, which makes it easier to see specific groups. Notably, religious institutions tend to not have very high postgraduate financial success, and there is a very visible decrease in the personal success as financial success increases. The military schools are also very interesting, because they consist of schools with high stem percentages, a relatively high income, and between 60% - 70% personal success. Tech schools have the biggest income range, however the amount of personal success felt by graduates doesn’t appear to change with income. This is possibly due to regional differences in incomes, as graduates fill the same employment positions but in different regions.
Scatter plot of tech schools






To look into the idea of tech not changing depending on income can certainly be seen in this graph here. While it may look like several schools in the middle of the income range are more personally successful, this likely isn’t significant due to these schools only ranging ~15% from the linear regression. Regionally, some regions do have more higher income schools, such as New England and the Pacific, and other regions like West South Central make up most of the lower income schools. While this matches the hypothesis made earlier, these results likely aren’t statistically significant, because of the low amount of data points.
To conclude, there is a relationship between personal success and financially success, with higher financial success generally leading to decreasing personal success. However, there are a variety of factors relating to this, not just geography like was hypothesized in our project proposal. These factors include, stem percentage, category of school, and of course geography.
Some limitations of this project were a lack of other variables, as well as sloppy categorization. As categories were made from buzzwords within the name of schools, some schools which could qualify as a certain category were not categorized.
Some future directions for this research would be to include school size, school prestige, and percentage of graduate vs. undergraduate students.

title: 2  Xavi W. Effective Teamwork
text:
Its very important to have effective teamwork, because you can get a lot more work done as a team then alone. Here are some key tips to have effective teamwork.

Communication is very important, you need to listen well and be open to new ideas. Feedback is also really important to help people grow.
Its important to have a shared vision, and understand what everyone in the group wants to achieve. It also important to have clear roles and responsibilities, and delegate roles effectively.
Its important to build mutual respect, and trust. This can help with conflict resolution.
Leadership is also important, because you can provide support and be empathetic.

Source: https://www.aces.edu/blog/topics/finance-career/10-tips-for-effective-teamwork-in-the-workplace/

title: 3  Laurice J. Effective Teamwork
text:
What Makes a Strong Team
Dependence on Each Other Team members know they need each other to succeed. They value both personal and team goals. Because of this, they don’t waste time competing against each other—instead, they work together.
Trust Team members trust each other and feel safe sharing their thoughts. This open environment makes it easier to ask questions, speak up, disagree respectfully, and come up with better solutions together.
Ownership Everyone takes pride in the team’s work. Because they care about the team’s success, they stay committed and put in the effort.
Using Individual Strengths Each team member brings something unique. Great teams let people use their skills and knowledge to help reach team goals and support the organization.
Open Communication Team members communicate clearly and make sure they understand each other. This builds trust and avoids confusion.
Constant Learning Strong teams encourage learning and growth. Members are supported when they try new things, even if they make mistakes—they see it as part of the learning process.
Team Decision-Making Everyone’s input is valued in decision-making. While the leader may make the final call if needed, the team works together to find the best solutions.
Resolving Conflict Well Good teams handle conflicts quickly and in a healthy way. People are open and honest, which helps solve issues without drama.
Source: https://davidburkus.com/2023/12/6-tips-for-effective-teamwork/#:~:text=Set%20Clear%20Goals,to%20guide%20your%20team’s%20journey.

title: 4  Munya M. Effective Teamwork
text:
Effective Team Work


Shared Goals: A team needs a clear understanding of the overall objective and how individual contributions fit into overall objective.


Accountability and Ownership: Team member ought to be accountable for their tasks and understand their responsibility.


Individual Strengths: Leveraging the unique skills and talents of each member allows for more efficient and effective work. Conflict Resolution: Being able to address disagreements constructively and find solutions together is essential.


Positive Attitude: A positive and supportive team environment promotes collaboration and motivation.

Source: https://www.aces.edu/blog/topics/finance-career/10-tips-for-effective-teamwork-in-the-workplace/

title: 5  Xavi W. EDA
text:
Research Question: What is the effect of state on post graduate success? 1. How does state relate to salary growth? 2. How is salary potential related to the percentage of graduates who make the world a better place? 3. How does state relate to the amount of stem graduates?
These questions should help answer the question of whether certain states have a relationship with higher post graduate success. Success is measured in two ways, economic: salary potential, and social: personal fulfillment.

title: 6  Laurice J. EDA
text: Research Question: What is the effect on religion on post graduate success.

title: 7  Munya M. EDA
text:
7.1 Research Question:
How do early and mid-career pay levels vary across U.S. states, and what roles do STEM enrollment and alumni perception (making the world better) play in this variation?

title: 7  Munya M. EDA
text:
7.2 Why this is important?
Career Planning for Students: students can make informed decisions about which schools or states offer better long-term financial prospects Especially relevant for students deciding between STEM and non-STEM paths.
Education Policy and Funding: It highlights states or institutions that produce high-earning graduates, which could inform public investment or scholarship programs.
STEM and Social Impact Balance: It examines whether higher STEM enrollment aligns with better salary outcomes — and whether that comes at the expense of perceived social impact; promoting discussion on balancing career success with societal contributions.
Economic Mobility and Equality: Understanding salary outcomes across states helps assess regional disparities in economic opportunity.It may inform state-level efforts to improve education outcomes and workforce development.

title: Appendix A — Proposal
text:
Geography and its relation with Post-Graduate Success Xavi Wernli, Munya Masvaure, Laurice Jimu
This project summarizes the relationship between geography (by U.S. state) and post-graduate success.
Post-graduate success is comprised of both economic success (salary), and social success (personal fulfillment). The project is meant to highlight how geography influences both economic and social outcomes of graduates.
We chose this projects because as university students concerned with our futures, we want to make sure we chose the right school to attend.
We just need to make a couple of graphs demonstrating the different relationships. This does also require producing summaries of each state for each variable, as currently the data is listed in universities. We will divy up the work load as we see fit.

title: Appendix B — Case Study
text:
The article studies the effects of Uber on taxicabs in NYC. The data finds that the amount of rides is not increasing; rather Uber is taking riders away from taxis. This replacement is especially significant in Manhattan, where Uber has taken over 4 million rides away from taxis.
This case study make a couple of very nice graphs describing how Uber has taken ridership from taxis overtime, partially driven by the pandemic.
Source: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/uber-is-taking-millions-of-manhattan-rides-away-from-taxis/
